metadata.title: Assembly and Electronic Applications of Colloidal Nanomaterials

Jian Zhu and Mark C. Hersam*

have improved the monodispersity of nano material dispersions, resulting in increasing uniformity in shape, size, and electronic purity.[5,9–11]
While an individual nanomaterial can be utilized in prototype devices to perform desired functions,[12] the complexity and current lack of effective scale-up methods have hindered the transition of device concepts from the research laboratory to commercialized technologies. Consequently, macroscale assembly of nanomaterials has emerged as an alternative approach to utilize and exploit nanomaterial properties in a scalable manner.[13] Indeed, by viewing colloidal nanomaterials as artificial atoms or building blocks, metamaterials have been self-assembled into
superstructures by a spectrum of driving forces.[14–17] Solidstate metamaterials with distinctive properties have also been realized via moldable and printable colloidal dispersions.[18,19] Building off these developments, recent years have witnessed colloidal nanomaterials as cost-effective, electronically active components of high-performance field-effect transistors (FETs),[20,21] light-emitting diodes,[22,23] solar cells,[24,25] and sensors.[26,27]
Among these devices, FETs are a key component of most modern-day electronics, and have emerged as the prototypical electronic platform for studying the fundamental principles of charge transport.[28] Therefore, as a unifying theme here, we focus on the assembly of colloidal nanomaterials for FETs. While the highest-performance FETs are required for microprocessor applications, a number of other technologies, such as the driving transistors for liquid-crystalline displays (LCDs) and organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), can be realized with moderate-performance FETs with low fabrication cost and largearea scalability.[28,29] Electronic materials based on colloidal nanomaterials, fabricated by highly scalable solution-based assembly techniques, are thus strong contenders in a competitive field that includes semiconducting polymers, amorphous silicon, and amorphous oxide semiconductors.[28–30] A key advantage of colloidal nanomaterials is their intrinsic mechanical flexibility derived from their nanoscale thickness, which renders them compatible with a variety of flexible and stretchable substrates,[31–35] and is thus particularly important for emerging wearable electronics. In select cases, the electronic performance of assembled nanomaterial solids has approached that of the corresponding single-crystal materials, creating further opportunities for high-performance applications.[20,36] Efforts to understand charge transport in colloidal-nanomaterial-based
Artificial solids and thin films assembled from colloidal nanomaterials give rise to versatile properties that can be exploited in a range of technologies.

sections.heading: In particular, solution-based processes allow for the large-scale and low-cost production of nanoelectronics on rigid or mechanically flexible substrates.
sections.text: To achieve this goal, several processing steps require careful consideration, including nanomaterial synthesis or exfoliation, purification, separation, assembly, hybrid integration, and device testing. Using a ubiquitous electronic device – the field-effect transistor – as a platform, colloidal nanomaterials in three electronic material categories are reviewed systematically: semiconductors, conductors, and dielectrics. The resulting comparative analysis reveals promising opportunities and remaining challenges for colloidal nanomaterials in electronic applications, thereby providing a roadmap for future research and development.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Colloidal nanomaterials are dispersions of nanostructured solid-state materials stabilized by surfactants, ligands, or charges on their surfaces. Due to quantum confinement and size-dependent interfacial and thermodynamic properties at the nanoscale, these materials possess unique electrical, optical, magnetic, chemical, and/or structural properties,[1–4] fueling efforts to synthesize and isolate a growing number of zero-, one-, and two-dimensional nanomaterials. Bottom-up chemical synthesis has been a popular approach historically,[5] while the rise of graphene and other two-dimensional nanomaterials has accelerated the utilization of top-down liquid-based exfoliation for large-volume production of colloidal dispersions.[6–8] A significant challenge facing the reproducible application of these colloidal nanomaterials is the typical heterogeneity in shapes and/or size immediately following synthesis or exfoliation.[9] Increasingly sophisticated growth and separation methods
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201603895
2 wileyonlinelibrary.com © 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
R ev
ie w FETs have also begun to benefit the design of related electronic systems, such as photovoltaics.[24,37]
We present here a comprehensive overview of recent advances in the assembly of colloidal nanomaterials for FETs. Section 2 delineates the basic principles and materials requirements of FETs. Section 3 presents the synthesis, purification, and separation approaches for monodisperse nanomaterials suitable for FETs. Section 4 surveys the assembly methods for achieving desired thin films or patterned substrates. Section 5 details colloidal semiconducting nanomaterials including inorganic nanocrystals or quantum dots (QDs), single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), and two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials. Section 6 addresses electrically conductive nano materials, namely metallic nanoparticles and carbon-based nanomaterials, which are well-suited as electrodes and interconnects for FETs. Section 7 provides an overview of the assembly of insulating nanomaterials for dielectric layers in FETs. Finally, we conclude with an outlook for the integration of these nanomaterial assemblies, with a particular emphasis on the opportunities and challenges for practical applications.

sections.heading: 2. Transistor Principles and Requirements
sections.text:
As basic elements of modern digital electronics, FETs are three-terminal devices, in which the current flowing between the source and drain electrodes through the semiconducting channel is controlled by the voltage applied to the gate electrode. A dielectric layer separates the semiconductor channel from the gate electrode, forming a metal–insulator–semiconductor FET (Figure 1A). Dictated by the doping of the semiconductor, the charge carriers can be holes or electrons, differentiating FETs into p-type, n-type, or ambipolar categories. By plotting the source–drain current (Id) versus the gate voltage (Vg), one obtains the transfer characteristic of an FET, such as the n-type example shown in Figure 1B.[38] Depending on the source–drain voltage (Vd), FETs can be operated in the linear regime or the saturation regime. Id is related to the fieldeffect mobility (μ), the channel-width-to-length ratio (W/L), areal capacitance of the gate dielectric (Ci), threshold voltage (VT), Vg, and Vd according to the following equations:

From these equations, it is evident that the mobility can be extracted from a linear fit of Id versus Vg in the linear regime (i.e., ΔId/ΔVg in Figure 1B) or the square root of Id in the saturation regime.[39] The linear (μlin) and saturation (μsat) mobilities may differ in value.[40] μsat is often larger than μlin due to second-order effects, such as charge trap states and the less noticeable contact resistances in the saturation region.[32,41] It should also be noted that μsat might be smaller than μlin for some nanocrystal FETs.[20,40] High mobilities are generally required for fast FETs and large drive currents. A minimum mobility of 1.5 cm2 V−1 s−1 is required to drive the operation

FETs in digital circuits generally require an on-state-tooff-state current ratio larger than 103.[42] FETs can be further categorized as depletion-mode or enhancement-mode, corresponding to whether they are in the on-state or off-state when Vg = 0 V, respectively. These two types of FET are incorporated in different circuit designs for specific functions. For example, in a complementary metal-oxide–semiconductor (CMOS) configuration, p-type and n-type enhancement-mode FETs with well-separated threshold voltages are needed to offer the benefits of high noise margin and low static power consumption.[21,43] Depletion or enhancement operation modes can be realized through the control and tuning of VT and subthreshold swing (i.e., the inverse slope of log(Id) versus Vg in Figure 1B). In addition, effective n-type and p-type doping schemes are needed for nanomaterials to enable flexibility in FET-circuit and system designs.[44–46]
Minimal hysteresis is another important factor when evaluating electronic materials for FETs. Bulk defects or dangling bonds at buried interfaces (e.g., between neighboring nanomaterials, nanomaterials/dielectrics, and nanomaterials/metallic contacts)
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201603895
3wileyonlinelibrary.com© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
R ev iew
often lead to large charge trap densities, making hysteresis a nearly ubiquitous issue in nanomaterial FETs.[21,47,48] The adsorption of water or oxygen onto the dielectric or nanomaterial surfaces may also induce defect states that induce hysteresis.[49,50] These midgap states have a significant influence on bias-stress stability and low-frequency noise or current fluctuations.[50–53] Consequently, encapsulation and surface passivation are typically needed to minimize hysteresis and enable consistent FET operation.[21,54,55] In addition, the temperature constraints of common plastic substrates necessitate low processing temperatures and novel annealing techniques for the fabrication of flexible electronics.[56]

sections.heading: 3. Nanomaterials for Solution-Processed FETs
sections.text: The preparation of electronic-grade nanomaterials for functional devices requires scalable synthesis/exfoliation methods and separation/purification strategies. In this section, we present a review of these important aspects for the semiconducting, conductive, and insulating nanomaterials required for FET applications.

sections.heading: 3.1. Preparation of Stable Nanomaterial Dispersions
sections.text:
The preparation of stable nanomaterial dispersions or inks is a prerequisite for most practical applications. The colloidal stability enabled by electrostatic and steric effects is engineered through the control of colloidal surfaces, which usually involves the assistance of organic surfactants unless inherent charges are induced during nanomaterial synthesis. The binding of the nanomaterial surface and surfactant molecules is realized via two well-established methods, namely, bottom-up chemical synthesis and topdown exfoliation (Figure 2A,B), both of which have shown great promise for large-scale production of colloidal nanomaterials.
The bottom-up chemical synthesis of colloidal nanomaterials is based on the guided crystallization of dissociated atoms from
precursors with the assistance of organic surfactants at suitable temperatures.[3,4,58–62] The growth of nanocrystals initiates with a nucleation event, and proceeds toward larger crystallites using the atoms from the precursors. At a later stage, surface effects lead to Ostwald ripening (OR), in which small crystals shrink while the larger ones continue to grow, leading to a wide distribution of sizes.[5,63] Three strategies are commonly used to lower the size distribution: i) burst nucleation, ii) size-focusing growth, and iii) delayed OR.[5,57,64] These techniques effectively suppress uncontrolled nanocrystal growth, and lead to the production of relatively uniform nanocrystals with tight size and shape distributions. Based on the growth conditions, nanocrystals can also dynamically attach to each other in a highly oriented fashion or recrystallize to form complicated shapes.[60]
The kinetic manipulation of reaction agents and conditions leads to the growth of different nanocrystals, including quantum dots, nanoparticles, nanorods, and nanosheets.[3,5,58,59,61,65] Diverse noble-metal nanocrystals including Au,[66,67] Ag,[68,69] Pt,[70,71] and Pd,[72,73] have been synthesized by reducing metal ions in the presence of stabilizing agents in organic or aqueous solutions. More-reactive metals, such as Cu,[74,75] Ni,[76,77] Co,[78,79] Fe,[80,81] and Cr,[82] have also been synthesized through rigorous control of the reaction conditions in inert atmospheres. The high electrical conductivity of metallic nanomaterials make their assemblies suitable for electrodes, and their diverse work functions can be exploited to match the semiconducting channel, thus lowering the contact barrier. In addition to metallic nanostructures, successful synthetic pathways for semiconducting nanocrystals have been achieved. Examples include monodisperse II–VI or IV–VI metal chalcogenide nanocrystals, such as CdX[83–86] or PbX[87–92] (X = S, Se, Te), III–V metal pnictide nanocrystals, such as InP or InAs,[93–96] and metal oxides, such as TiO2,[97,98] In2O3,[99,100] ZnO,[101,102] or FeOx.[103,104] In addition to these inorganic quantum dots and nanoparticles, atomically thin inorganic sheets have been experimentally realized, such as PbS,[105] SnSe,[106] CdSe,[107] CdS,[107] CdTe,[107] Bi2Se3,[108] MoSe2,[109] WSe2,[109] SnO2,[110] and CeO2,[111] through controlled anisotropic growth or oriented

Cost-effective applications of nanocrystals hinge on the consistency and robustness of their synthesis upon scaleup. Multiple reports have shown that at least tens of grams of nanocrystals can be synthesized without sacrificing qua lity.[57,68,69,104,112,113] For example, 40 g of 12 nm diameter iron oxide nanocrystals with a size variation of 2.3% have been synthesized by reacting iron chloride with sodium oleate in 1-octadecene.[104] Similarly, 140 g of monodisperse Ag nanoparticles
have been prepared in a semiaqueous solution in the presence of p-mercaptobenzoic acid.[68] More recently, 215 g of Cu2−xS with a size variation of less than 7% was produced using highconcentration precursors in a manner that can also be extended to PbS and CdS nanocrystals (Figure 2C).[57]
While bottom-up chemical synthesis is effective for a variety of nanomaterials with different electronic properties, some materials are more easily isolated by top-down exfoliation in solution. In this approach, the inputted energy overcomes the weak van der Waals forces between the crystal planes or nanomaterial aggregates, leading to exfoliated nanostructures that

are stabilized in solution with the assistance of surfactants. This approach has proven to be effective for dispersing carbon nanotubes,[114,115] graphene oxide,[116,117] pristine graphene,[118–120] hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN),[121–123] 2D transition-metal dichalcogenide (TMD) nanosheets,[7,124,125] black phosphorous,[126,127] and other 2D nanomaterials.[7,128–130] Small amphiphilic molecules (e.g., sodium cholate, sodium dodecyl sulfate, pyrene derivatives, Pluronic and Tetronic block copolymers, polyelectrolytes, and even organic solvents) can serve as surfactants to lower the exfoliation energy and preferentially adsorb to the surface of nanostructures in aqueous or nonaqueous solutions.[119,125,126,131–134] Sources of energy for exfoliation include sonication,[134] ball milling,[123] shear-mixing,[8] and high-pressure homogenization.[135]
Intercalation of small molecules or ions has been an effective strategy to improve the yield of solution-based exfoliation. For example, intercalated acids have been used to enhance the exfoliation of graphene from graphite.[136,137] Furthermore, single-layer TMDs are realized by the intercalation of Li, Na, and K ions,[138–140] while the production of atomically thin MXenes is facilitating by selective chemical etching and intercalation.[141,142] Intercalation-based approaches, however, often introduce irreversible structure and property changes,[140] some of which have been exploited for applications such as lowcontact-resistance electrodes.[143] Liquid exfoliation is relatively amenable to scale-up. For example, large-volume production of 2D graphene (Figure 2D), h-BN, and TMDs has been realized by shear mixing.[8,144] Shear mixing has also been applied to scale-up pristine graphene inks that use ethyl cellulose as a stabilizer.[56,145–147]

sections.heading: 3.2. Separation Methods for Improving Nanomaterial Monodispersity
sections.text:
As-synthesized or exfoliated nanomaterials often show polydispersity in size or shape, leading to inhomogeneous properties that are undesirable in emerging technologies. For example, despite steady advances in controlling chirality of SWCNTs during growth,[148] as-synthesized SWCNTs still contain metallic and semiconducting mixtures. While a particularly poignant example, SWCNTs are not alone among a series of nanomaterials that demand effective and scalable strategies for sorting, fractionation, and purification.
Centrifugation is a widely applied technique to separate heterogeneous colloidal nanomaterials. A simple form is termed as differential centrifugation,[149] in which tubes containing nanomaterial dispersions are spun directly without adding extra density-gradient media. This centrifugal approach is commonly used to separate the byproducts or extra surfactants from the desired nanomaterials, or serves as a preliminary step for purification or concentration before further separations.[121,125] Due to the different sedimentation rates of nanomaterials traveling in the solvent, the solution can be centrifuged at a cascade of progressively higher speeds to partially sort the nanomaterials according to their densities. Recently, liquid-exfoliated monolayer WS2 has been enriched in this way by centrifuging the as-sonicated dispersions at a series of speeds.[150]
To improve the sorting specificity, other chemical agents can be added into dispersions to affect the solubility or centrifugation response of targeted nanomaterials. For example, gradual injection of poor solvents has been used to lower the stability of nanocrystals to yield size-selective precipitation.[83,151] Similar approaches have been used to flocculate graphene/ethyl cellulose following exfoliation.[152,153] The versatility and control of this approach are exemplified by SWCNT sorting via discriminating conjugated polymers. Polyfluorene and polythiophene derivatives or copolymers have been heavily investigated to target specific chiralities of SWCNTs.[154–162] These polymers have achieved varying levels of success in sorting CoMoCAT, HiPco, laser ablation, and arc-discharge SWCNTs due to their different ranges of diameters.[159] In the best case, semiconducting SWCNTs with greater than 99% purity have been isolated by this approach.[157,161] In addition, single-handedness SWCNT enantiomers have been separated using conjugated polymers with chiral moieties.[163,164] Following sorting, it is necessary to strip the poorly conductive conjugated polymers from the tube walls to improve the charge transport, but their strong affinity for SWCNTs defies effective removal through rinsing at low temperatures.[165] One method for releasing these polymers is to trigger their conformation change by acids[166] or chelating agents.[167] Another strategy incorporates sacrificial bonds, such as coordination bonds,[156] hydrogen bonds,[168] or imine bonds,[157] in polyfluorene-based supramolecular copolymers. These sacrificial bonds can be selectively cleaved with acid treatments, leading to the flocculation of relatively pristine SWCNTs.[156,157,168]
Density-gradient ultracentrifugation (DGU), developed initially for biochemistry,[149,169] is another separation strategy based on centrifugation, which utilizes density-gradient media to influence the motion of nanomaterials in centrifugal fields. Continuous linear density gradients can be prepared prior to ultracentrifugation, or can be induced to form during ultracentrifugation, depending on the diffusion coefficients of the density-gradient media.[119,125,132,170] Stepwise or nonlinear density gradients have also been successfully employed.[170,171] DGU approaches can be classified into two categories: rate-zonal DGU (sometimes referred to as transient DGU) and isopycnic DGU (sometimes referred to as equilibrium DGU).[149,172]
Rate-zonal DGU is a sedimentation-based separation, which is particularly suitable when the buoyant densities of the nanomaterials are larger than the limits of the density-gradient medium. In this approach, the original nanomaterial dispersions are introduced at a predetermined position with respect to the density gradient, and then the centrifugation speed and duration are controlled to enable differential sedimentation. This strategy has been successfully applied to separate gold rhombic dodecahedra from gold bipyramids in a density-gradient medium of iodixanol,[173] which results in visibly colored bands in the centrifuge tube (Figure 3A–C). Similarly, gold nanorods have been separated from competing reaction products using sucrose as the density-gradient medium.[174] Other examples that employ aqueous density-gradient media include MoS2 nanosheets,[175] nanodiamonds,[176] zeolite nanosheets,[177] and Fe/Co graphitic-shell nanocrystals.[178] Nanocrystals dispersed in organic solvents, such as Ag,[179] Au,[179] CdSe,[179] CdS,[180] and Si,[181,182] have also been sorted in

non-aqueous density gradients, which are typically formed by layering organic solvents of different densities.
In contrast, isopycnic DGU is an equilibrium-based separation, in which nanomaterials are separated on the basis of their buoyant densities.[149] In this case, nanomaterials sediment through the density gradient until they reach the position where their densities match that of the surrounding medium. Depending on the density of the targeted nanomaterial, the original nanomaterial dispersion is either layered at the top or bottom of the density gradient.[119,121] This technique has been widely employed for sorting SWCNTs in aqueous surfactant solutions,[9,119,131,132,170,171,183–188] resulting in SWCNT fractions that have been enriched by diameter or chirality (Figure 3D),[183,186] length,[184] or enantiomeric identity.[185] Furthermore, by exploiting the differential affinity of sodium cholate and sodium dodecyl sulfate for metallic and semiconducting SWCNTs, the ratio of these two surfactants has been optimized to realize high-purity metallic or semiconducting SWCNT dispersions.[132,189] For example, SWCNTs with metallic or semiconducting purities in excess of 99% have been prepared and are available commercially.[190] In addition, isopycnic DGU has been extended to the sorting of 2D nanomaterials, such as graphene,[119] h-BN (Figure 3E,F),[121] and 2D TMDs,[125] using iodixanol-based density-gradient media. A key innovation for 2D nanomaterial sorting was the replacement of the small-molecule surfactant sodium cholate with bulkier Pluronic block-copolymer surfactants, whose larger hydration-layer thicknesses reduce the buoyant density of the nanomaterials in aqueous density-gradient media, leading to effective isopycnic sorting of 2D TMDs[125] and multilayer h-BN.[121]

Additional noncentrifugal methods have also been developed for separating nanomaterials with the most effort being devoted to SWCNTs.[9,148,191] Specific examples include ion-exchange chromatography,[192,193] gel chromatography,[194–196] and twophase partition.[197,198] While each method has advantages for particular separation targets, their limited generality for a broad range of nanomaterials has hindered their widespread adoption, particularly for industrial-scale separations.[190] Readers that are interested in these alternative separation methods are referred to a recent review.[11]

sections.heading: 4. Assembly Techniques for Thin-Film Fabrication and Patterning
sections.text: Integrating nanomaterials into FETs requires reliable assembly methods to fabricate uniform thin films and laterally defined patterns. This research field has achieved significant progress, and some technologies have been reviewed in detail for different purposes.[199–201] Our goal in this section is to present a critical survey of different methods important for assembling electronically relevant components based on colloidal nanomaterials, and their potential integration into electronic devices.

sections.heading: 4.1. Evaporation-Based Assembly
sections.text:
Drop casting, spin coating, dip coating, spray coating, and blade coating are major evaporation-based assembly techniques. These methods are not limited to colloidal nanomaterials, and are widely adopted for liquid inks in many material systems. The maturity and applications of these assembly techniques have also inspired the development of related advanced fabrication techniques.
Drop casting (Figure 4A) is a facile film-forming technique. It usually proceeds by casting a large drop of colloidal nanomaterial on a substrate, followed by solvent evaporation until the film is completely dried. A challenge that plagues this assembly method is the difficulty to form homogeneous thin films due to the “coffee-ring” effect.[202] However, by controlling the evaporation conditions, it is possible to organize QDs or other nanocrystals into superlattices or supercrystals,[87,203] providing promising assemblies for electronic applications.
Spin coating (Figure 4B) is a widely used technique to create high-quality thin films. In this process, drops of colloidal nanomaterials are dispensed on a substrate, which is then accelerated to high angular velocities (hundreds to thousands of rpm) to spin off excess solution, resulting in a thin uniform coating. Solvent evaporation takes place during the spinning, and makes the coating solid-like due to the dramatic increase of viscosity.[204] This method has been widely used to prepare glassy QD thin films[40,90] and carbon-nanotube networks.[205,206] The major advantages of this method are its reproducibility, simplicity, low cost, and easy integration with conventional microfabrication techniques. However, as a batch process, it is not compatible with roll-to-roll (R2R) processing on continuous plastic substrates. In addition, this method wastes most of the colloidal solution during the film-formation process and
has difficulty in achieving uniform coatings on non-planar substrates.
Dip coating (Figure 4C) relies on the adsorption of nanomaterials to the substrate when it is immersed in the colloidal dispersion or during the withdrawal process from the liquid. The immersion–deposition procedure has been used to create SWCNT random networks via electrostatic or hydrophobic forces by dipping a surface-modified or untreated substrate into SWCNT aqueous or organic dispersions.[154,207–209] Thicker QD films, such as PbSe or PbS, can be deposited by repeating the dipping process to achieve final thicknesses of 30–40 nm, allowing them to be used in photodetectors or solar cells.[24,210] In addition, the withdrawal–deposition process is often executed with a controlled substrate-retrieval rate, which correlates well with the final coating thickness from sub-monolayer to several multilayers. Slow evaporation during substrate withdrawal has enabled wafer-scale PbSe and PbS nanocrystal superlattices.[211] Furthermore, dip coating can be used to create densely aligned SWCNTs by withdrawal–deposition due to confinement effects at the air–water interface.[212,213] The interface can be alternatively manipulated with slowly evaporating solvents instead of withdrawing substrates to align SWCNTs.[214,215]
Spray coating (Figure 4D) is another useful thin-film fabrication technique, in which fine colloidal droplets are deposited on heated substrates to ensure immediate solvent evaporation and film uniformity. The viscosity of spray-coated inks has to be low to facilitate the nebulization process for small droplets. This technology is especially useful for coating uneven structures, such as steps, trenches, and stacks on semiconductor chips,[216] and can be used to fabricate thin films using nanomaterials, such as SWCNTs, CdTe, or CuInSe2 nanocrystals.[217–219] In addition, the deposition outcome can be further tuned by annealing at suitable substrate temperatures.[220]
Blade coating (also known as knife coating or doctor blading) is an easily implementable approach that requires colloidal inks with higher viscosities than the other techniques discussed in this section. In this process, an ink is spread into a uniform film by a blade or rod moving above the substrate, with the film thickness dictated by the fixed gap between the blade and the substrate.[200] An advantage of this technique is that the high ink viscosities minimize nanomaterial movement during drying, resulting in little to no coffee-ring effects. However, the increased amount of additives that is needed to produce ink formulations with sufficiently high viscosities typically compromise the electronic properties, necessitating post-processing to remove them from blade-coated films.[221] A series of conductive thin films (e.g., Ag,[222] Cu,[221] and SWCNTs[223]) that are potentially useful for FET applications have been prepared in this way.

sections.heading: 4.2. Assisted Assembly Methods
sections.text:
The organization of nanomaterials in thin films directly affects their morphology, defects, and electronic properties with ordered packing usually resulting in superior film quality and device performance. The low-dimensional characteristics of nanomaterials present unique challenges and opportunities in this regard. Here, we particularly discuss Langmuir–Blodgett
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201603895
8 wileyonlinelibrary.com © 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
R ev
ie w
(LB) or Langmuir–Schaefer (LS), layer-by-layer (LBL), fieldassisted, and vacuum-assisted assembly.
LB/LS assembly (Figure 4E), initially designed for amphiphilic organic molecules,[224] is a powerful technique for building nanomaterial monolayers. In this approach, nanomaterials are typically introduced to the surface of an aqueous subphase through the spreading of volatile organic solvents, followed by compression via two physical barriers, one on each side, to reduce the occupied area until a fully packed monolayer is formed. Process control is achieved by monitoring the concomitant surface pressure during monolayer formation. The floating, well-packed nanomaterial monolayer can either be transferred onto a slowly withdrawing substrate via dip coating (i.e., LB assembly) or transferred to a stamping substrate that is approached from above or below the monolayer surface (i.e., LS assembly).[225] This method enables high coverage of
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201603895
Figure 4. Methods for nanomaterial assembly. A) Drop casting. B) Spin coating. C) Dip coating. D) Spray coating. E) Langmuir–Blodgett assembly. F) Layer-by-layer assembly. G) Field-assisted assembly. H) Vacuum-assisted assembly. I) Inkjet printing. J) Aerosol-jet printing. K) Gravure printing. L) Screen printing. M) Electrodynamic jet printing. N) Direct-write/3D printing. O) Microcontact printing. P) Confined assembly.
9wileyonlinelibrary.com© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
R ev iew nanoparticles[226] or nanosheets,[227] and a concurrent alignment of nanorods[228] or SWCNTs[36] on the substrate. While most of the nanomaterials suitable for LB/LS assembly require stable dispersions in volatile organic solvents, amphiphilic nanosheets including graphene oxide[227] or calcium niobate[229] dispersed in water have also been shown to be compatible with LB/LS assembly. Although LB/LS assembly enables close packing of nanomaterials, the sensitive processing conditions and the requirement of a water subphase presents limitations for large-scale production.[200]
LBL assembly (Figure 4F) is a cyclic process that precisely deposits nanometer-thick films on desired substrates.[230–232] It typically involves two oppositely charged materials (e.g., a positively charged polymer and a negatively charged colloidal nanomaterial) with one adsorbed on the substrate first, and then the other adsorbed on top of the first layer following rinsing. These procedures can be repeated to build up films of a desired thickness. The rinsing step between layers is effective in removing loosely bound materials and thus improving the film uniformity, although in some cases, rinsing is not required if the materials can be precisely dispatched.[233] Each LBL step can be deposited in different ways, leading to the development of immersive, spin, spray, inkjet, or R2R LBL assembly.[232] Therefore, LBL assembly is a versatile technique for the scalable production of a variety of nanomaterial thin films.[134] While the polymers involved in the assembly can render beneficial properties for composite films,[19] their presence is typically detrimental to electronic properties, which necessitates the development of removal processes.[121,234]
Field-assisted assembly (Figure 4G) aims to align nanowires, nanorods, or nanotubes into well-packed thin films through the application of electric or magnetic fields. Alignment by magnetic field is less commonly used for electronic applications since prior attachment of magnetic nanoparticles to nonmagnetic nanomaterials are usually required for effective alignment.[235] Instead, alternating-current (AC) electric fields are more practical for orienting 1D nanomaterials based on their induced dipole moments.[236–238] This phenomenon, known as dielectrophoresis, is used to densely align SWCNTs or nanowires in an inhomogeneous electric field formed between a pair of planar microelectrodes.[239–241] Particular control of electrode design and hydrodynamic force even enables deterministic dielectrophoretic assembly of single nanorods or nanotubes at pairs of electrode sites.[237,238,242] To reduce curving defects of SWCNTs in conventional dielectrophoresis, a fringingfield dielectrophoretic assembly was developed that applies an AC voltage between surface microelectrodes and the substrate, which results in well-aligned, ultrahigh-density, and sub-monolayer semiconducting SWCNT arrays.[236] Although field-assisted assembly is an effective alignment approach, it is difficult to achieve large-scale uniformity for wafer-scale applications.
Vacuum-assisted assembly (Figure 4H) is typically achieved by flowing a dispersion of nanomaterials through a porous membrane subjected to a vacuum-induced pressure difference. The nanomaterials are separated from the carrier solvent by the membrane, and gradually accumulate in a self-regulated way into a homogeneous thin film.[243] This filtration-based method conveniently allows rinsing of the thin films to remove
undesired surfactants. 1D nanomaterials deposited in this way typically form a uniform but randomly oriented network unless special care is taken for alignment,[244] whereas 2D nanomaterials tend to assemble into a lamellar structure. The porous membranes assisting the assembly can be either sacrificial cellulose-ester-based membranes that allow for easy removal after contact transfer,[21] or rigid nanoporous alumina membranes that permit thin-film transfer via poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS) stamps.[245] Initially used for forming transparent conductive electrodes from SWCNTs,[243,246] this assembly method has been more broadly applied to create large-scale SWCNT networks for FET channels,[21,43] in addition to enabling thin films of graphene[119] and related 2D semiconducting nanosheets.[247]

sections.heading: 4.3. Micropatterned Assembly Methods
sections.text:
Assembly of nanomaterials at predetermined locations is an essential requirement for fabricating electrodes or channels for functional FETs. Although the methods discussed above are effective for fabricating uniform thin films, additional patterning via optical lithography and etching is needed, which typically requires high-cost facilities and may interrupt streamlined production. Therefore, assembly methods for colloidal nanomaterial inks that concurrently provide patterning control are highly desirable. In this section, we briefly review several patterning processes based on nanomaterial inks that are widely used for fabricating FETs.
Inkjet printing (Figure 4I) is a versatile manufacturing tool that precisely deposits picoliter volumes of fluid on arbitrary substrates.[248] Commercial office-use inkjet printers can be adapted to print nanomaterial inks,[233] while some manufacturers provide higher-performance inkjet printers with additional powerful capabilities for materials research.[56,153] To fully exploit this equipment, suitable nanomaterial inks need to be formulated with appropriate surface tension and viscosity to enable proper droplet generation and subsequent drying after printing. A general rule of thumb to ensure droplet formation is to make the inverse Ohnesorge number, Z = (γρa)−0.5/η, where γ, ρ, a, and η are the surface tension, density, characteristic length, and dynamic viscosity, respectively, lie within the range of 1 < Z < 10.[248] A lower value of Z prevents drop ejection, while a higher value of Z produces satellite droplets, although it should be noted that inks with Z outside this range can sometimes be printed under specialized conditions.[249] A high solid content in the ink is usually preferred, but is limited by the stabilizing mechanisms of the constituent colloidal nanomaterials and the maximum allowed viscosities (typical ink viscosities range from 1 to 100 cP).[199] In addition, to create uniform profiles of the droplets after drying, several strategies, such as suppressing outward capillary flow, promoting inward Marangoni flow, and controlling sliding of contact lines, can be employed to minimize coffee-ring effects through appropriate choice of solvents, substrates, and deposition conditions.[250] A growing library of nanomaterial inks (e.g., Ag, graphene, and SWCNTs)[145,251] has been developed for inkjet printing. The resolution of inkjet printing is usually limited to 20 μm[252] unless patterned substrates are used to confine the wetting or transport of droplets.[249,250]
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201603895
10 wileyonlinelibrary.com © 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
R ev
ie w Aerosol-jet printing (Figure 4J) is another drop-based direct-writing technology.[253] Analogous to spray printing, it requires
nebulization of inks into 1–5 μm droplets, which are then confined to microscale dimensions by an annular sheath gas flow before deposition (Figure 4J).[254] An electromagnetic shutter is responsible for delivering predetermined amounts of aerosol mist to prescribed locations on the substrate.[255] The sheath gas rate, printing velocity, nebulization gas rate, nozzleto-substrate distance, and substrate properties can affect the printing resolution, which is usually limited to 10–20 μm.[256] The coffee-ring effect is also an important concern for ink formulations.[255] Compared to inkjet printing, inks for aerosol-jet printing are usually more flexible in terms of particle loading, viscosity, and surface tension.[253,255] For example, aerosol-jetprinting ink viscosities can range between 0.5 and 2500 cP.[254] In addition, due to the high nozzle-to-substrate distance, aerosol-jet printing is compatible with nonplanar substrates.[254] Despite these advantages, aerosol-jet printing usually suffers from overspray, which leads to unwanted peripheral deposition beyond the intended printed features.[255] A range of nanomaterial inks formulated for inkjet printing are also suitable for aerosol-jet printing.[255,256] Even highly diluted inks, such as aqueous dispersions of semiconducting SWCNTs, have been aerosol-jet printed.[257,258]
Gravure printing (Figure 4K) is a printing technology that utilizes direct ink transfer through physical contact of engraved structures on a rotating cylinder with the substrate.[199] In a standard gravure process, the engraved microcells are flooded with ink, after which excess ink is removed by a doctor blade, and then transferred to a flexible substrate between the engraved and impression cylinder.[199] The entire process can be automated and integrated into an R2R mass-production line. The process can also be manually performed using a patterned silicon wafer as an engraved stamp with subsequent steps of ink flooding, excess ink removal, and impression-based printing.[152] Since the continuous printed features require spreading and merging of ink from neighboring cells,[152] gravure-printable inks typically possess a lower viscosity than screen-printing ones. Nevertheless, the viscosity can be higher than in inkjet printing, which enables higher nanomaterial loading and superior printing fidelity. Similar to inkjet printing, the surface energy of the target substrate affects the wettability of the ink and thus the printing resolution, which can be optimized to the range of 30–50 μm.[152,199] Gravure printing has been successfully used to fabricate electrodes and dielectrics for FETs.[152,259]
Screen printing (Figure 4L) is a noncontact printing technology realized by spreading an ink through a patterned screen with a squeegee. To avoid leakage migrating across the designed open windows, high-viscosity inks are typically required in screen printing.[200] The resolution of screen printing is dependent on the screen mask, which is usually attained by photochemically patterning polymers on a screen mesh.[147] However, this conventional method for making screen masks only affords a resolution of 40–120 μm, corresponding to a screen-printing resolution of 50–150 μm.[147] Higher-resolution screen masks have been achieved by using a silicon stencil, which can be photolithographically patterned and etched into finer openings as small as 5 μm, leading to a
printed line resolution down to 5 μm.[147] In addition, inks with higher viscosity tend to copy more exactly the patterns from the screen mask for higher resolution and higher aspect ratio. Screen printing has been previously used for building electrodes and dielectrics for FET applications.[146,147,260,261]

sections.heading: 4.4. Higher-Resolution Patterning
sections.text:
Since the printing approaches discussed in the preceding section rarely achieve direct patterning with feature dimensions below 10 μm, they cannot compete effectively with conventional photolithography for high-density integration of electronic devices. Therefore, significant effort has been devoted in the research community toward the development of higherresolution patterning methods for nanomaterial inks, as will be outlined in this section.
Electrodynamic jet printing (Figure 4M) exploits electricfield-induced flow to eject ultrafine droplets from nozzles with an inner diameter as small as several hundred nanometers.[262–264] It is impractical to use such a small nozzle in conventional inkjet printing due to the extreme pressure required to overcome the capillary force.[265] The narrow nozzles are fabricated by pulling glass pipettes or via a conventional microfabrication process.[263,266] A thin layer of gold is usually coated on the nozzle tips to make them conductive, and sometimes a hydrophobic coating is subsequently applied to reduce the wetting of inks on the nozzle walls. In a typical process, a syringe pump delivers ink to the tip of the nozzle, where the meniscus of the ink deforms into a conical shape (i.e., a Taylor cone) under sufficiently high electric fields with consequent droplets ejecting from the apex. This operation mode is known as the pulsating-jet mode.[263] At higher electric fields, an uninterrupted stream of ink is ejected from the nozzle because of the continuous presence of the Taylor cone, leading to cone-jet-mode operation.[263,265] Both the pulsating-jet and cone-jet modes afford high-resolution and controllable deposition of inks.[265] The electric field enabling these two operation modes is typically several MV μm−1, which requires the tip to be close to the substrate to minimize the applied voltage. For example, a 100 μm stand-off distance requires a voltage of 110–900 V for effective printing.[263] In order to overcome the accumulation of charges on highly insulating substrates, ACpulse-modulated electrodynamic jet printing has been developed with more-precise control of printing speeds and droplet sizes.[267] To prevent clogging, the nanomaterial dimensions need to be much smaller than the nozzle size. In this manner, SWCNTs, semiconducting QDs, Ag nanoparticles, Si nanorods, and related nanomaterials have been deposited by electrodynamic jet printing with feature sizes ranging from 10 μm down to the nanoscale regime.[263–265,267,268]
Direct-write printing (Figure 4N), which can also be used for 3D printing, employs the extrusion of highly viscous nano material inks into continuous microscale filaments or fibers that are precisely placed at desired locations via a 3-axis micropositioning stage.[269–271] The extrusion can be driven by either compressed air or screw motion, enabling the use of fine nozzles with clogging prevented by properly formulated inks. For example, a nozzle as small as 1 μm has been employed to
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201603895
11wileyonlinelibrary.com© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
R ev iew achieve a minimum line width of ≈2 μm for silver-nanoparticle inks.[269] Similar to electrodynamic jet printing, single-channel nozzles are produced from glass capillary tubes,[269] while multichannel nozzles are fabricated via micromachining.[272] Inks suitable for direct-write printing typically have a shearthinning rheology, which allows the inks to flow when extruded through the nozzle, but are then stationary when deposited.[269] Unlike other printing approaches that are limited to 2D-only features, 3D architectures can also be built by this method, such as spanning lines or other complex structures through layering or nozzle design.[269,273–276] Direct-write printing is particularly suitable for high-resolution interconnects or electrodes in FETs and other electric components in 3D electronics. Various nanomaterials, such as Ag,[269] QDs,[270] SWCNTs,[277] graphene,[278] and graphene oxide,[271] have been formulated into inks compatible with this printing technique.
Microcontact printing (Figure 4O) is a transfer-based, highresolution printing method. Conventional lithography is used to fabricate a photoresist master that contains patterned relief structures on the surface, from which a PDMS stamp with complementary patterns is cast.[279] Nanomaterials are then inked on the PDMS stamp, after which high-fidelity patterns are transferred to the target substrate.[200,280] For example, LBaligned SWCNTs have been picked up by patterned PDMS stamps, and subsequently transferred to silicon or plastic substrates.[281] Inking can also occur indirectly by adopting a donor substrate to supply thin nanomaterial films to PDMS stamps.[282] The chemical compatibility of PDMS can be improved with protective coating layers, such as parylene or SU-8, although the changed surface energy can complicate the transfer process.[200] Sub-10 μm resolution is routinely achieved with microcontact printing, and features as small as 100 nm are feasible with additional care.[279] A major concern of this printing method is the transfer yield, which is affected by several processing parameters.[200] Nevertheless, microcontact printing has been a useful technique for FET fabrication.[283,284] In particular, metallic and semiconducting SWCNT networks have been patterned with microcontact printing for FET electrodes and channels, respectively.[283]
Nanoimprint lithography is another high-resolution patterning technique. Similar to microcontact printing, this method also requires conventional lithography to fabricate relief patterns on a solid surface, which are then used as a stamp or a mold for creating PDMS patterns.[285–287] In a typical process, a rigid stamp is pressed into an imprint fluid, and the direct mechanical contact transfers high-fidelity patterns from the stamp to the fluid.[285] This process can create feature sizes of tens of nanometers in the high-resolution limit. In applications related to the assembly of nanomaterials, the imprint fluids can be either thermoplastic polymers or nanomaterial inks.[200] Polymers, such as poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) or thermal imprint resists, which are mobile under heat, can form matrices accommodating nanomaterials[288] or sacrificial patterns allowing for lifting off.[289] For nanomaterial inks, PDMS stamps are usually employed to conformally contact the target substrate with the nanomaterials trapped in the confined space.[290,291] Slow evaporation of the solvents enables the deposition of patterned nanomaterial assemblies. It should also be noted that nanoimprint lithography is compatible with
R2R processes for large-scale applications.[286] Despite these advances, nanoimprint lithography is still an emerging technique for the fabrication of nanomaterial FETs,[292] requiring the integration of different materials with proper alignment.
It is important to acknowledge that conventional lithography is still a vital tool for fabricating solution-processed FETs with high-resolution features. Following deposition on target substrates, nanomaterial thin films are often patterned by photolithography or electron-beam lithography to fabricate FETs on silicon or flexible plastic substrates. The low-dimensional characteristics of the nanomaterials enable them to self-assemble differently in the confined nanochannels (Figure 4P), leading to alignment,[293] unique placement,[294] or distinctive chargetransport properties.[295] This type of confined self-assembly has been realized for SWCNTs,[293,296,297] Au nanoparticles,[294] QDs,[298] and related nanomaterials.[298]

sections.heading: 5. Semiconducting Nanomaterials for High-Performance FETs
sections.text: Semiconducting nanomaterials are essential components in FETs, whose performance depends not only on the intrinsic properties of the nanomaterials but also on their surface properties, geometrical arrangements, and connections in assembled thin films. Advances in the synthesis and sorting of nanomaterials have created a growing library of semiconducting nanomaterial inks capable of producing high-mobility FETs. The last decade has also witnessed their continuous development and integration into increasingly functional circuits, as well as their applications in conformal and flexible electronics. Specifically, semiconducting QDs, carbon nanotubes, and atomically thin nanosheets have received considerable interest as FET channel materials.

sections.heading: 5.1. Semiconducting Inorganic Nanocrystal Solids
sections.text:
Chemically synthesized inorganic nanocrystals, especially based on QDs, have emerged as strong candidates for semiconducting channels in FETs due to their uniform sizes, compositions, and shapes, enabling their assembly into close-packed nanocrystal solids with the potential for band-like electronic transport.[10] However, it is generally challenging to realize the expected performance of nanocrystals due to charge-transport barriers from surface ligands. This problem typically cannot be overcome by high-temperature sintering, which tends to leave carbonaceous residues, defects, dangling bonds, and charge trap centers. Attempts to overcome these challenges have attracted significant attention as outlined in multiple review articles.[2,10,299–301]
Close-packing of nanocrystals is a prerequisite for highmobility transport. Entropy dominates the assembly of monodisperse nanocrystals when the inter-nanocrystal interaction is relatively weak, which leads to dense packing of nanocrystals.[302–304] In contrast, many forms of spin coating and drop casting lead to the formation of locally ordered and glassy nanocrystal arrays.[305] During solvent evaporation, the increased viscosity at high nanocrystal concentration freezes the liquid-like structure, in which nanocrystals find local
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201603895
12 wileyonlinelibrary.com © 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
R ev
ie w optima in position at time scales on the order of seconds. [305] In these glassy thin films, each nanocrystal is surrounded tightly with neighboring nanocrystals with close-packed spacing, but this order is only short-ranged. For example, this glassy behavior is evident in scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging of PbTe solids and related grazing-incidence smallangle X-ray scattering (GISAXS) spectra that are characterized by uniform, diffuse rings (Figure 5A).[90] Long-range ordering of nanocrystals in thin films, often referred as superlattices or supercrystals, can be realized by controlled drop casting with slow solvent evaporation, which allows nanocrystals to have sufficient time to find their equilibrium sites.[305] Slow destabilization rates of dispersed nanocrystals facilitate the homogeneous growth of ordered superlattices[305] with grain sizes ranging from tens of nanometers to several hundred micrometers.[87,306] For example, a hexagonally close-packed arrangement of PbS nanocrystals can be observed in transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging and sharp spots in GISAXS measurements at the square-millimeter scale (Figure 5B).[87] Nanocrystal superlattices have recently been achieved at the wafer scale by a dip-coating method that exploits slow withdrawing and evaporation rates,[211] as well as blade coating with relatively fast drying.[307]
The proximity between inorganic nanocrystal cores in closepacked thin films directly affects charge transport.[2,10,300] The distance between the nanocrystal cores is usually dictated by the surface ligand size, which exponentially influences the charge-tunneling rate.[2] Ultimately, at minimum interparticle distances, strong coupling occurs with wavefunctions of neighboring nanocrystals overlapping to form an extended electronic state.[10] This strong coupling enables charge transport evolving from low-mobility hopping transport between localized electronic states to high-mobility band-like transport through delocalized electronic states.[10] This transition and the resulting dramatic improvement in charge-carrier mobility have been realized by the exchange of compact ligands that replace the long ligands involved in nanocrystal synthesis.[10,300]
The efficacy of ligand exchange depends on the interaction between ligands and nanocrystal surfaces. Classically, there are three types (i.e., X-, L-, and Z- type) of metal-ligand interactions depending on the number of involved electrons and the charge-transfer characteristics.[60,300,301] X-type ligands are anionic one-electron donors (e.g., carboxylates: RCOO−, thiolates: RS−, and phosphonates: RPO(OH)O−), L-type ligands are neutral two-electron donors or Lewis bases (e.g., amines: RNH2, phosphines: R3P, and phosphine oxides: R3PO), and Z-type ligands are neutral two-electron acceptors or Lewis acids (e.g., Pb(OOCR)2, CdCl2, and AlCl3).[60,300,301] Ligand exchange is more favorable within the same category of ligands, and is affected by solvent polarity, the ligand affinities to nanocrystal surfaces, and the relative abundance of incoming and outgoing ligands.[300] For example, the X→X’ ligand exchange is more feasible than X→L’ and is facilitated by polar solvents, since nonpolar solvents limit an electrically neutral nanocrystal surface.[300] Under appropriate conditions, stable dispersions of nanocrystals decorated with compact ligands can be prepared by solution exchange preceding assembly into semiconducting thin films.[10,300] The ligand exchange can also be implemented
following assembly, but this process often induces defects and voids due to the resulting volume shrinkage of the films.[10,300] Along with short organic ligands, such as 1, 2-ethanedithionl or pyridine, a growing number of inorganic ligands, such as hydrazine, chalcogenidometallates (e.g., Sn2S64−, In2Se42−, CdTe22−), halometallates (e.g., PbCl3−, InCl4−), chalcogenides (e.g., S2−), halides (e.g., Cl−, I−), and pseudohalides (e.g., SCN−, N3−), have been developed.[10,300]
The electronic coupling between nanocrystals can be further enhanced by thermal annealing. Volatile ligands, such as hydrazine,[91] pyridine,[300] and alkylamine,[322] can be removed by annealing to improve interparticle interactions. High temperatures also induce sintering of nanocrystals into large crystallites through grain growth (Figure 5C). Since the fusion of nanocrystals stems from the increased mobility of surface atoms at high temperatures, surface ligands can significantly influence the sintering behavior. Typically, grain growth commences at ≈200 °C,[20,40] but the original nanocrystal size and phase can be maintained until 300°C with different surface ligands.[322] While nonvolatile ligands often serve as defects in the grown crystalline domains,[322] compositionally matched compact ligands can effectively alleviate this problem. For example, it was recently shown that (Cd2Se3)2− ligands serve as electronically transparent grain boundaries in annealed CdSe nanocrystal thin films, leading to record FET performance with a linear regime mobility of 210 cm2 V−1 s−1, and a saturation regime mobility of 180 cm2 V−1 s−1, as well as high-performance output characteristics (Figure 5D,E).[20,40]
Assembly of nanocrystals into superlattices with ligand-free boundaries provides an additional pathway for strong electronic coupling.[323,324] This assembly of nanocrystal arrays is realized by oriented attachment, which is a well-accepted mechanism for anisotropic growth of colloidal nanocrystals.[5,60] Most studies have focused on oleic-acid-capped PbSe nanocrystals,[323–328] whose adjacent specific facets can lose ligands and join epitaxially together under controlled conditions. This superlattice assembly and oriented attachment usually occur at liquid–liquid interfaces,[323,324,326] although structures with reduced long-range ordering can also be observed via direct displacement of ligands with amines[327] or dimethylformide.[325] It should be noted, however, that even in the ligand-free case, disorder resulting from the intrinsic polydispersity of nanocrystals leads to a limited localization length.[323] Nevertheless, the charge-carrier mobilities in these unintentionally doped nanocrystal solids have been shown to be 13 cm2 V−1 s−1 by four-probe measurements,[324] and 0.2–0.5 cm2 V−1 s−1 at 245 K according to FET measurements.[323]
Several nanocrystals have been investigated for their charge-transport properties, including CdSe,[20,31,32,40,308–311] PbSe,[44,45,47,91,312–315] PbS,[316] InAs,[93] InP,[93] HgTe,[317,318] and ZnO,[319,320] which are presented in Figure 5F. In agreement with the previous discussion, the carrier mobility is dependent on the surface ligands and annealing temperature, even for the same type of nanocrystals. Since inorganic ligands are smaller than short-chain organic ligands, they are generally more effective at facilitating charge transport in nanocrystal solids. For example, SCN− has proven to be a suitable ligand for both CdSe[31] and PbSe[313] with en hanced mobilities of 25 and 7 cm2 V−1 s−1, respectively, after ligand exchange and doping,

ie w while organic ligands [299,300,313] have topped out at a mobility of ≈1 cm2 V−1 s−1.
Controlling the FET polarity (p-type or n-type) via doping of nanocrystal solids is critical to realizing logic functions in integrated circuitry. Toward this end, several doping strategies have been developed.[10,329,330] For example, remote doping has been realized by exposing nanocrystal surfaces to chemical treatments that introduce impurity atoms or alter nanocrystal stoichiometry.[10] Specifically, exchange ligands can induce charge transfer or doping in nanocrystal solids,[91] and chalcogen- and metal-rich surfaces lead to p-type or n-type charge transport, respectively.[44] In addition, doping has been achieved by incorporating impurity atoms at the substitutional and interstitial sites in the nanocrystal cores through controlled reactions or cation exchange.[331,332] Furthermore, the polarity of FETs depends on the charge-injection electrodes. Low-work-function aluminum contacts favor n-type FETs, whereas high-work-function palladium contacts favor p-type FETs.[313] While most of the high-performance nanocrystal FETs are n-type (Figure 5F), p-type FETs have also been realized with electron-withdrawing dopants, such as oxygen, hydroxides, or chalcogenides.[44,45,312]
The switching speed of a transistor is another key factor in electronic circuits. The transit time depends on charge-carrier mobility, channel length, and the electrical field between source and drain.[308] This relationship is quantified by the formula for maximum switching frequency f, which is expressed as f = (Eμ)/L = (Vdμ)/L2, where E is the electric field, L is the channel length, μ is the mobility, and Vd is the source–drain voltage.[308] Since L is limited by the patterning technique and Vd should be smaller than 5 V for low voltage operation, μ plays a significant role. In addition, hysteresis in the transport characteristics can have deleterious effects in practical applications.[308] A hysteresis-free CdSe-nanocrystal FET showed a cut-off frequency of 13 kHz, agreeing with predictions for L = 150 μm, μ = 1 cm2 V−1 s−1, and Vd = 3 V.[308] An improvement of μ and reduction of L has allowed increases in cut-off frequency to 2.3 MHz (Figure 5G).[40]
Air stability and low hysteresis are required for nanocrystal FETs to have useful applications. Nanocrystals, especially n-type chalcogenides, are notoriously prone to oxidation, due to their shallow work function.[24] Therefore, the fabrication and measurement of nanocrystal FETs are usually performed in gloveboxes or other inert environments.[321] The high surface-to-volume ratio of nanocrystals makes their electronic properties particularly sensitive to surface adsorbates and dangling bonds, which introduce trapping sites and thus hysteresis in the transport characteristics. Encapsulation of nanocrystal surfaces by Al2O3 using atomic-layer deposition (ALD) has proven to be an effective strategy for passivating electron traps, in addition to serving as a diffusion barrier to suppress oxidation.[47,321] In particular, encapsulated CdSe FETs have shown minimal performance degradation for timescales in excess of 2 months (Figure 5H),[321] with similar results being reported for PbSe FETs.[47] In addition, conventional photolithography has been used to pattern electrodes with indium metal dopants that render nanocrystal films tolerant to chemical and environmental exposure.[321] Recently, it has also been found that iodide (I−) can bind strongly to PbS surfaces to repel oxidative attack.[24] Beyond encapsulating nanocrystals, dielectrics with reduced trap densities also decrease hysteresis and improve device performance.[40,45,312,333]
The availability of high-performance and consistent nanocrystal FETs has allowed the fabrication of integrated circuits on rigid and flexible substrates.[32,308] Specifically, low hysteresis and high mobility (≈10 cm2 V−1 s−1) n-type CdSe FETs have been reliably fabricated on large-area Kapton substrates (Figure 5I,J). These FETs were used to construct NOT (i.e., inverters), NOR, and NAND logic gates. These inverters showed a noise margin of 1.13 V at VDD = 5 V,[32] and have also been used as analog voltage amplifiers with a bandwidth of 6.8 kHz.[32] Ring oscillators built from these inverters show a 7.7 μs delay per stage at VDD = 2 V,[32] markedly improved in comparison to previous designs with a delay per stage of 600 μs (Figure 5K,L).[31] Complementary inverters based on n-type and p-type PbSe nanocrystal FETs with full rail-to-rail voltage swing, high noise margins, and low power consumption have also been realized.[45,313]

sections.heading: 5.2. Semiconducting SWCNT Networks
sections.text:
The availability of high-purity semiconducting SWCNT inks has inspired the exploration of random or aligned SWCNT networks for high-performance FETs. Translating the exceptional properties of individual SWCNTs to those of SWCNT networks requires optimized assembly, contacts, and encapsulation strategies. Many studies are focused on these topics, together with excellent reviews about SWCNT devices in general.[30,148,334–337] In this section, we summarize recent progress on solution-processed SWCNT FETs.
One typical geometry for solution-processed SWCNTs is random networks. These networks can be reliably transferred to an arbitrary substrate from a sacrificial membrane following vacuum filtration (Figure 6A).[21,43,338] Alternatively, SWCNT networks can be deposited by dip coating, where the assembly is further facilitated by electrostatic interactions between charged surfactant-wrapped SWCNTs and amine-modified surfaces (Figure 6B),[34,209,339] or by van der Waals or hydrophobic interactions between conducting-polymer-wrapped SWCNTs and chemically modified dielectric substrates.[154,207] Patterns of SWCNT random networks can also be aerosol-jet or inkjet printed.[257,258,340,341] The SWCNT density needs to be beyond the percolation threshold to form an electrically continuous network between the source and drain electrodes,[342] but should not be too large to reduce gate modulation due to screening effects from the excess SWCNTs in the network. The innate trade-off between field-effect mobility and on/off ratio often requires a meticulous optimization of SWCNT densities to achieve desirable device performance.[338] Charge transport is also affected by the purity of semiconducting SWCNTs. Even trace amounts of metallic SWCNTs can degrade FET performance by forming percolating pathways that short the channel,[343] in addition to the fact that the contact resistance between a metallic SWCNT and a semiconducting SWCNT is approximately 100 times greater than that between two semiconducting SWCNTs.[344] Polydispersity in the chirality of semiconducting SWCNTs can also introduce problems since SWCNTs with narrower bandgaps tend to dominate charge transport in networks, which can limit on-currents and effective carrier mobility.[46] Furthermore, similar to nanocrystal solids, residual surfactants at tube–tube contacts reduce the intertube coupling, which implies that their
