Another attractive ensemble of SWCNTs is aligned networks, which can enable higher SWCNT packing density and thus higher current output. LS assembly,[36] field-assisted assembly (Figure 6C),[236,240] confined assembly in narrow channels (Figure 6D),[296,297,345,346] and evaporation-induced assembly at the water/air interface during dip coating (Figure 6E)[165,212,214,215] are effective methods for inducing SWCNT alignment. The highest density of aligned SWCNTs for FETs has been realized by LS assembly, creating a doublelayered SWCNT structure with an estimated tube density in excess of 1000 tubes μm−1 and a pitch of 1.8 nm that is limited only by the SWCNT diameter and van der Waals separation.[36] Other alignment methods[165,240,297] have achieved SWCNT arrays with densities between 30–50 tubes μm−1 with some bundling and curving defects. A sub-monolayer of SWCNTs with a consistent pitch as small as 21 ± 6 nm was realized by fringing field dielectrophoretic assembly (Figure 6C). These aligned arrays can either be integrated into long-channel FETs operating in the percolative regime, or into short-channel FETs operating in the direct-transport regime.[36,165] The latter devices require highly purified semiconducting SWCNTs, since the presence of even one metallic SWCNT can short the transistor channel. High tube densities also increase electrostatic screening, thus requiring high-capacitance dielectrics to effectively gate the SWCNT channel.[36]
The electrostatic coupling between SWCNT arrays and the gate electrode is more complicated than a parallel-plate capacitor, especially for a sparse SWCNT network.[347,348] The gate coupling can be rigorously determined by including the effects of the SWCNT quantum capacitance and intertube coupling.[347] The capacitance of the substrate depletion region also needs to be taken into account when silicon is used as a back gate.[36] Quantitative analysis shows that the intrinsic gate capacitance increases with increasing SWCNT density, and gradually approaches the dielectric capacitance defined by the parallel-plate model.[347] The difference between the intrinsic gate capacitance and the parallel-plate capacitance is more significant with lower SWCNT density or higher dielectric capacitance. The intrinsic gate capacitance can also be directly measured in some cases.[33]
The on-state conductances and mobilities of selected solutionprocessed SWCNT FETs[36,43,132,155,165,207,208,213,214,236,257,296,297,338] versus channel length are shown in Figure 6F,G. Note that the mobilities in comparison here are estimated using the parallel-plate capacitance as the gate capacitance, as is generally accepted for benchmarking SWCNT FETs against conventional FETs.[338] Due to the overestimation of the gate capacitance, the intrinsic mobilities of SWCNT networks are higher than the mobilities presented in Figure 6G. Two observations can be made from the comparison: i) aligned SWCNT arrays and shorter channel lengths usually lead to higher on-state conductances. However, in the percolative transport regime, the on-state conductances of optimized random SWCNT networks[338] can match those of aligned SWCNT arrays. It is also likely that FETs made from aligned SWCNTs are still not optimal, with their performance limited by the tube–tube junction resistance and surfactant residues.[36] ii) The mobilities
of long-channel FETs containing random SWCNT networks range from 1 to 50 cm2 V−1 s−1, which are higher or comparable to solution-processed organic and inorganic FETs.[349] In comparison, the mobilities of short-channel FETs with aligned SWCNTs are often unexpectedly similar or worse due to parasitic resistance at the contacts, which considerably degrades the apparent short-channel mobilities.[36] By subtracting the contact resistances, the mobilities of short-channel devices have been estimated to be 130 ± 20 cm2 V−1 s−1 (symbol m in Figure 6G), close to those of individual solution-processed SWCNTs (≈300 cm2 V−1 s−1).[350] The contact resistance can be reduced with increased wetting of contact metals on SWCNTs or endbonded contacts through the reaction of SWCNTs with deposited metals, such as Mo.[36,351]
Controlled doping for p-type and n-type SWCNT FETs is desirable for CMOS digital-logic circuits. As-fabricated SWCNT FETs typically show p-type behavior in ambient conditions due to the adsorption of oxygen and water vapor,[352,353] as well as the low Schottky barrier heights for holes for most air-stable metal contacts,[336] such as Pd or Au. In order to obtain reliable n-type FETs, suitable surface passivation by Al2O3[21,354] or SiO2,[355] or an inert testing environment is necessary to minimize ambient dopants. Although low-work-function contact metals,[355–357] such as Er, La, Y, Sc, Gd, have been employed to lower the electron-injection barrier for n-type individual SWCNT or aligned SWCNT network FETs, such methods have not yet been demonstrated for random SWCNT network FETs.[336] Surface charge-transfer doping by electron-withdrawing molecules or polymers, such as hydrazine,[358] viologen,[359] 1H-benzoimidazole derivatives,[207] polyethylenimine[354,360] has provided an alternative means for achieving n-type SWCNT FETs. In addition, fixed positive charges in the passivation layer, such as HfOx[361] or SiNx,[362,363] can induce n-type field-effect doping of the underlying SWCNT networks. Charge transfer that enables n-type doping is also expected to occur for low-work-function metal oxides based on Y, Sc, Er, and La. In addition to p-type and n-type FETs, ambipolar SWCNT FETs have been obtained through doping with AlOx,[353,361] using ion gels as electrolytes,[257,258] or passivating SWCNTs with PMMA and HfOx after desorbing water and oxygen from the surface.[46]
Low hysteresis and air stability of SWCNT FETs are also essential to the design, fabrication, and operation of large-scale integrated circuits.[21] Hysteresis typically originates from trap states in the gate dielectric or by charges induced by ambient adsorbates in the vicinity of the SWCNTs.[54,55] In particular, the hydroxyl groups in typical oxide dielectrics attract water and serve as interface defects, thus contributing significantly to hysteresis.[54,364] Preventing water adsorption and reducing dielectric trap states via the use of hydrophobic dielectrics, such as self-assembled nanodielectrics,[338,365] or encapsulation layers, such as AlOx[21,354] or fluoropolymers,[55,366] have proven to be effective approaches for realizing the reliable and stable operation of SWCNT FETs. Figure 6H–J show the stable operation of large-scale p-type and n-type SWCNT FETs that employ effective doping/encapsulation layers.[21] In comparison to unencapsulated devices, encapsulated FETs possess low hysteresis, reproducible threshold voltages and on/off ratios, and high spatial homogeneity.[21] The temporal stability and consistent performance of both p-type and n-type enhancement-mode
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201603895
17wileyonlinelibrary.com© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
R ev iew SWCNT FETs hold promise for the fabrication of wafer-scale CMOS logic devices.
Significant progress has occurred in the utilization of highperformance SWCNT FETs for integrated circuits. Logic gates, such as inverters, NAND, and NOR, have been demonstrated using SWCNT FETs.[21,33,43,359,361,367] Since p-type SWCNT FETs are more easily fabricated, the logic gates typically adopt a p-type metal-oxide-semiconductor (PMOS) design.[336,367] Figure 7A,B show the respectable output characteristics of diode-loaded inverters or NAND logic gates made from p-type SWCNT FETs, confirming the function of the designed circuits.[33] These logic gates were fabricated on flexible polyimide substrates, making it possible to evaluate the endurance of SWCNT FETs under mechanical deformation. It has been shown that minimal performance change occurred under curvature radii as small as 1.3 mm and 2000 cycle bending tests.[33] Aerosol-jet-printed ambipolar SWCNT FETs have also been explored to make inverters and ring oscillators following a CMOS-like design.[257,258] The high mobilities of the SWCNT network and the use of an ion-gel dielectric resulted in fast ring oscillators with sub-5 μs stage delay time.[258] In these logic gates comprising solely p-type or ambipolar FETs, the devices possess significant steady-state power consumption due to high steady-state currents, in comparison to the low power dissipation in CMOS logic designs that incorporate both p-type and n-type enhancement-mode FETs.[21,43] The realization of p-type and n-type SWCNT enhancement-mode FETs with well-separated threshold voltages has since allowed highly integrated SWCNT-based CMOS electronics with ultralow power consumption.[21,43] Figure 7C,D provide the output characteristics of the resulting SWCNT CMOS inverters and NAND logic gates with ideal rail-to-rail operation, subnanowatt static power consumption, high gain, and excellent noise margins.[43] These SWCNT FETs were further optimized for large-scale static random access memory (SRAM) circuits with stable read and write operations (Figure 7E–G).[21]
Other n-type FETs made from alternative semiconducting materials, such as zinc tin oxide[370] or indium gallium zinc oxide (IGZO),[368] have also been integrated with p-type SWCNT FETs to realize CMOS logic. For example, SWCNT– IGZO hybrid CMOS inverters (Figure 7H) exhibit ideal rail-torail voltage behavior, and low steady-state currents of ≈190 pA (Figure 7I).[368] These well-behaved inverters have been further incorporated in 501-stage oscillators (>1000 FETs) with a stage delay of ≈5 μs.[368] Novel p–n heterojunction devices have also been explored using p-type SWCNT FETs. Figure 7J shows a gate tunable p–n diode consisting of a vertical stacking of p-type SWCNTs and an n-type monolayer MoS2 flake.[369] The monolayer thickness of MoS2 implies incomplete electrostatic screening, which allows both sides of the heterojunction to be tuned with an applied gate bias.[369] The superposition of the transfer characteristics of the p-type SWCNT FET and n-type MoS2 FET results in a unique anti-ambipolar behavior (Figure 7K).[369] The n-type MoS2 can be replaced with n-type IGZO for a more-scalable version of anti-ambipolar heterojunctions, which have been further utilized for frequency doubling and keying circuits.[371]
Beyond components for logic circuits, SWCNT FETs can also serve as switches for pixels in active-matrix displays,[372] pressure
sensors,[373] or responsive artificial skins.[34] Figure 7L presents a fabricated pixel incorporating a SWCNT FET, a pressure sensor, and an OLED for user-interactive e-skin.[34] The anode of the OLED is connected to the drain of an SWCNT FET, and the cathode is in electric contact with the pressure sensor. These three components are monolithically integrated over large areas on plastic substrates to visually detect the spatial distribution of applied pressures through the pressure-sensitive response of OLED brightness (Figure 7M,N).[34] The inherent imperfections of SWCNT FETs, such as limited semiconducting purity and random nanotube placement in confined channels, have also been exploited for unclonable cryptography applications.[374]

sections.heading: 5.3. Two-Dimensional Semiconducting Nanosheets
sections.text:
Recently, substantial interest has been devoted to the family of 2D semiconducting nanomaterials due to their atomiclevel thickness and outstanding electronic properties.[42,375–377] Materials of interest include TMDs,[378] black phosphorous,[379] silicene,[380] germanene,[381] and borophene.[382] Field-effect mobilities measured on mechanically exfoliated or chemical vapor deposition (CVD)-grown 2D nanomaterials range between 2 and 400 cm2 V−1 s−1 for semiconducting TMDs, and 40 and 1000 cm2 V−1 s−1 for black phosphorous.[375] Semiconducting 2D nanomaterial inks are also emerging, although charge transport in percolating networks has not yet achieved competitive performance.
The electrical properties of individual flakes after liquid exfoliation have been investigated. For example, electrochemically exfoliated MoS2 monolayers with lateral sizes as large as 50 μm show n-type transfer characteristics with mobilities of ≈1.2 cm2 V−1 s−1 and on/off current ratios above 106 (Figure 8A,B).[383] This decent FET behavior illustrates that the integrity of the 2H phase is maintained after exfoliation, in stark contrast with the partially recovered 2H phase from thermal annealing of lithium- or sodium-intercalated MoS2, whose FETs show significantly lower on/off current ratios.[138,384] The demonstrated mobility of solution-processed MoS2 is lower than the typical value for mechanically exfoliated or CVDgrown MoS2,[385,386] which likely results from defects generated during solution-based exfoliation or unoptimized electrical contacts and dielectrics. For example, the intrinsic mobilities of MoS2 flakes exfoliated in N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone have been estimated to be ≈160 cm2 V−1 s−1 after a theoretical exclusion of the Schottky barrier induced contact resistances.[247] In contrast, black phosphorous maintains its electronic integrity after being exfoliated with anhydrous organic solvents in a sealedtip ultrasonication system.[126] Morphological and spectral characterization has revealed that the structure and chemistry of solvent-exfoliated black-phosphorous nanosheets match those achieved by mechanical exfoliation. Fabricated FETs from solvent-exfoliated black-phosphorous nanosheets show high mobilities of ≈50 cm2 V−1 s−1 and on/off current ratios of ≈104 (Figure 8C,D).[126]
FETs based on assembled 2D nanomaterial networks have shown compromised performance. Specifically, negligible gate modulation and mobilities have been shown for drop-cast or inkjet-printed MoS2 thin films.[247,389] Small flake sizes, large

interflake contact resistances, and defects/traps generated during liquid exfoliation are leading culprits behind the poor FET performance. Some of these issues may be addressable by post-chemical treatments, as has been shown for FETs made from reduced graphene.[387] With high-temperature thermal annealing to restore the graphitic lattice and large flake sizes, FETs built from these reduced graphene nanosheets have shown carrier mobilities greater than 280 cm2 V−1 s−1, which can be further improved by ionic screening using electrolytes (Figure 8E).[387] Vertical FETs[390] are another emerging option, since the reduced channel length minimizes the number of inter-flake contacts. In an early study, the vertical transport of a ≈1.5 μm-thick MoS2 film was characterized using the spacecharge-limited current (SCLC) method, yielding an optimum electron mobility of 0.02 cm2 V−1 s−1 for ligands with a medium alkyl chain length of 0.75 nm (Figure 8F,G).[388]

sections.heading: 6. Conductive Nanomaterials for Electrical Contacts and Interconnects
sections.text:
Electrical contacts and interconnects are essential components to control the flow of charge carriers in FETs and integrated circuits.[391,392] In comparison to conventional vacuum-based metal-deposition methods, highly conductive nanomaterial inks, such as those based on Ag, Au, SWCNTs, and graphene, offer compatibility with cost-effective and flexible solution-based assembly approaches. In addition to providing high electrical
conductivity (Figure 9A), nanomaterial inks can equip electrodes and interconnects with additional functionality, such as stretchability or optical transparency (Figure 9B,C), stemming from the intrinsic nanomaterial properties, fabrication procedures, and polymer binders in the inks.

sections.heading: 6.1. Electrically Conductive Nanomaterial Inks
sections.text:
The electrical conductivity of nanomaterial assemblies is dependent on the intrinsic conductivity of the constituent nanomaterials and their electronic coupling in a network. It is natural to consider metals, such as Ag or Au, or carbon nanomaterials, such as SWCNTs or graphene, as likely candidates for this application due to their superlative intrinsic electrical conductivities (σAg = 6.3 × 105 S cm−1, σAu = 4.4 × 105 S cm−1, σSWCNT < 2 × 105 S cm−1, and σGraphene < 2 × 105 S cm−1).[251,393–396] Similar to semiconducting nanocrystals, conductive nanomaterials require a layer of surfactants on their surfaces in order to preserve dispersion stability, but at the expense of introducing nonconductive residues in deposited films. Ligand exchange has proven to be effective for enhancing electrical conductivity.[407] For example, the compact SCN ligands can allow the assemblies of Ag or Au nanocrystals to have conductivities of 1.1 × 105 S cm−1 and 2 × 104 S cm−1, respectively.[289,290] Alternatively, surfactant removal or increased metallic grain sizes through sintering show comparable or more-promising results.[251] Unlike semiconducting nanocrystals, the defects introduced during

Ag-nanoparticle inks are the most commonly used conductive inks, since Ag routinely shows the highest electrical conductivity.[251] Ag nanoparticles in these inks are typically polydisperse in size, and can have diameters of tens of nanometers.[408] Ag nanowires are also employed as components in conductive inks.[409] The viscosity of Ag inks is tuned by adjusting the nanoparticle or binder concentrations to meet the requirements of a variety of printing methods including inkjet printing,[255] aerosol-jet printing,[255] pen writing,,[398] screen printing,[260] gravure printing,[259] and direct-write (3D) printing.[269] Ag inks have proven to be effective materials for fabricating electrical contacts in a variety of FET structures.[259,260,410,411] The contact resistances of printed Ag electrodes are typically higher than those achieved by vacuum-based evaporation, due to Ag oxidation during annealing and the reduced contact area that results from the roughness of the printed electrodes.[410,412] In particular, inkjet-printed Ag electrodes typically have a contact resistance of 1.8 MΩ cm in comparison to 0.55 MΩ cm for evaporated Ag electrodes in the bottom-contact geometry.[412] Planar and 3D Ag interconnects have also been demonstrated.[269,413] An example of Ag 3D interconnects for the operation of an LED is shown in Figure 9D.[269] The spanning features are realized via direct-write printing using shear-thinning Ag inks comprising more than 70 wt% nanoparticles.[269]
Other metal inks, such as Au[397] and Cu,[414] have also been explored. Au nanoparticles, despite their high conductivity and stability, are limited by their prohibitive cost for applications in printed electronics.[415] Cu is much less expensive than Ag, but Cu nanoparticle inks are more easily prone to oxidation in ambient conditions.[251,415] Therefore, it is important to select suitable surfactants that can act as a passivation layer to minimize Cu oxidation.[416] In most cases, the surfactant shells can only slow down but not prevent oxidation.[251] In order to improve long-term stability, increasing efforts are devoted to the synthesis of Cu nanoparticles with protective inert metallic shells.[417] However, it is unclear whether the final cost of air-stable Cu inks obtained by more complicated synthesis methods can remain lower than that of Ag inks.
SWCNT inks present a carbon-based alternative to metallic nanoparticle inks. In comparison to metallic nanoparticles, SWCNTs are lighter, stronger, and more chemically and thermally stable.[145] Pristine SWCNTs dispersed with surfactants or organic solvents tend to have higher electrical conductivity than oxidized SWCNTs, and are therefore best suited for electrical contacts to FETs. Random SWCNT conductive networks prepared by spray coating have electrical conductivities of 1.1 × 103 S cm−1.[26] The resulting SWCNT electrodes can be coupled with SWCNT semiconducting networks for flexible or stretchable FETs.[35] The conductivity of SWCNT networks can be further improved by using high-purity metallic SWCNTs,[405] aligned SWCNTs,[418] or chemical doping.[134] The conductivity of iodine-doped, aligned SWCNT yarns can be as high as 5 × 104 S cm−1 at room temperature,[418] but the harsh production process and volatility of the dopants may make them unsuitable for FET electrodes. On the other hand, field-assisted assembly of aligned metallic SWCNTs may offer improved compatibility for electrical contacts (Figure 9E).[405] With such electrodes,
SWCNT FETs show an order of magnitude higher performance in terms of on-state conductance and mobility than FETs with the same geometry but using conventional Pd contacts.[405] More specifically, the on-state conductances and mobilities for SWCNT FETs with Pd contacts are 0.9 μS and 5 cm2 V−1 s−1, respectively, in comparison to 15.7 μS and 51 cm2 V−1 s−1 for SWCNT FETs with metallic SWCNT contacts.[405] Random SWCNT networks have also been used as electrodes in vertical FETs, allowing for high current output as is required for lightemitting devices.[419,420]
Graphene is another carbon-based option for conductive inks with attractive attributes, such as high conductivity, mechanical flexibility, and environmental and thermal stability.[145] Chemical or thermal reduction of graphene oxide is one route to produce reduced graphene oxide for printed electronics.[116] However, due to unrecoverable structural defects from the original oxidation process, the conductivities of reduced graphene oxide are usually limited to 100 S cm−1,[116] but may be enhanced to 650 S cm−1 after 1000 °C annealing.[387] When used as electrical contacts, thermally reduced graphene oxide assemblies deliver an order of magnitude enhancement of hole and electron mobilities for graphene FETs compared to Au electrodes.[387] Alternatively, pristine few-layer graphene can be produced via exfoliation of graphite in organic solvents, such as NMP, or in other organic or aqueous solutions with the assistance of surfactants.[6] Graphene/NMP inks are suitable for inkjet printing,[421,422] although the limited graphene loading and viscosity make these graphene inks incompatible with other printing methods.[145] The conductivities of printed graphene patterns are 30 S cm−1 at processing temperatures below 70 °C.[422] Ethyl cellulose can also be used as an effective surfactant to enable efficient exfoliation of graphene in ethanol, which is then flocculated and dried into graphene/ethyl cellulose powder.[153] The resulting composite graphene powder can be dispersed in a variety of solvents at a range of concentrations, allowing fine control of the graphene-ink properties, such as viscosity, surface tension, and drying kinetics, enabling compatibility with a range of assembly methods, such as inkjet printing,[153] screen printing (Figure 9F),[146,147] and gravure printing.[152] Mild annealing of the printed graphene patterns gives rise to high electrical conductivities of 250 S cm−1.[153] The properties of polymer-stabilized graphene inks can also be tuned for extrusion-based direct-write printing,[271,278] which can then be used for building 3D graphene interconnects in a manner analogous to Ag inks.[269]
The increasing interest in flexible electronics has inspired efforts to develop low-temperature annealing techniques that are fully compatible with heat-sensitive polymer substrates, such as poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET) or poly(ethylene naphthalate) (PEN), whose glass-transition temperatures are only 70 °C and 120 °C, respectively.[199] Toward this end, annealing techniques using various external energy inputs, such as intense pulsed light or lasers (i.e., photonic annealing),[56,423,424] plasmas,[425] microwaves,[426] electricity,[427] or chemicals,[428] have been investigated. These strategies localize sintering to the deposited conductive film, thereby minimizing heating of the underlying polymer substrate.[251,429] Photonic annealing has also been shown to be effective for graphene inks, enabling flexible graphene patterns on PET or PEN with similar conductivities to those annealed at 250 °C.[56]

ie w 6.2. Transparent or Stretchable Conductors
Nanomaterials can enable the fabrication of transparent or stretchable electric contacts or interconnects for next-generation electronics.[430,431] Since nanomaterials enable property combinations not observed in bulk materials, this added functionality is realized by more than just reducing the thicknesses for transparent conductors or including binders for stretchable conductors. Striking the optimal balance between contradicting material properties calls for creative materials engineering through the selection of suitable nanomaterials and their assembly methods.
Transparent conductors consisting of nanomaterials are cost-effective alternatives to doped metal oxides.[396,432,433] High-aspect-ratio nanostructures, such as 1D silver or copper nanowires or carbon nanotubes, and 2D graphene sheets, form percolating networks with minimal thicknesses, allowing low electrical resistance and high optical transparency.[399,434] A number of fabrication methods, including vacuum-assisted assembly,[119,435] blade coating,[221,436] spray coating,[26,35] and layer-by-layer assembly,[134,437] have been used to build and optimize transparent conductive films based on nanomaterial networks. The optical transmittance and sheet resistance of transparent conductors are typically interrelated. In particular, the optical transmittance depends on the coating thickness, absorption/scattering properties of the constituent nanomaterials, and voids left in the percolating networks, while the sheet resistance is a function of the intrinsic nanomaterial electrical conductivity, contact junction resistance, degree of percolation, and coating thickness.[396,399,438] To quantify these two parameters concurrently, a generally accepted Figure of merit uses the ratio of the DC to optical conductivity (σDC/σOP) to evaluate different nanomaterial networks.[396,399] Reported values of σDC/σOP for transparent conductors fabricated from colloidal nanomaterials are 215, 75, 14, 0.7 for Ag nanowires, Cu nanowires, SWCNTs, and graphene nanoflakes, respectively,[396,439] although these values are significantly affected by the diameters of the nanowires, assembly methods, doping, and purity levels. For example, the σDC/σOP value is improved by using high-purity metallic SWCNTs[246] or sorted monolayer graphene nanoflakes[119] in comparison to their as-synthesized counterparts.
A systematic investigation of transparent conductor networks reveals two governing mechanisms related to different ranges of transmittance (Figure 9B).[399] This analysis leads to the conclusion that smaller-diameter nanowires afford a better combination of high optical transmittance and electrical conductance. The haze caused by the scattering of nanowires can also be reduced by using finer nanowires.[438] State-of-the-art sheet resistances and optical transmittances at a wavelength of 550 nm for nanomaterial networks are 10 Ω sq−1 @ 85% for Ag nanowires,[440] 15 Ω sq−1 @ 86% for Cu nanowires,[441] 328 Ω sq−1 @ 79% for SWCNTs,[26] and 260 Ω sq−1 @ 86% for graphene flakes.[442] It is worth mentioning that inkjet printing can also be used to create microscale Ag grids for transparent conductors,[443] but these coatings might not be suitable for applications requiring nanoscale uniformity or small footprints.
Stretchable conductors are typically nanocomposites consisting of elastomers, such as PDMS or polyurethane, and percolating networks of conductive nanomaterials.[19,400–404,406,430,444–446]
Stretchability and conductivity are generally exclusive material properties since the inclusion of stiff conductive nanomaterials increases the electrical conductivity but also decreases the stretchability.[19] When optimizing these competing factors, several parameters need to be considered, such as the shapes and surface chemistries of the nanomaterials, mechanical deformation/relaxation, and assembly methods. One approach relies on the reversible deformation of buckling.[430,446] Percolating networks of SWCNTs[26] or Ag nanowires[400,406,444] are spraycoated to an elastomer substrate or inlaid as a top layer in an elastomer substrate. During the first stretching/recovering cycle, the resistance is increased significantly due to the irrecoverable loss of contacts between the 1D nanostructures.[26,400,406,444] At this stage, the different relaxing behaviors of the percolating networks and the elastomers cause the formation of buckling, either from the SWCNTs or from the Ag/elastomer top layer.[26,400] The buckled conductive coatings can then be stretched without causing further significant increases in resistance. With this strategy, SWCNT networks maintain a conductivity of 2200 S cm−1 at a 150% strain,[26] and Ag-nanowire networks retain a conductivity of 5285 S cm−1 at a 50% strain.[400]
An alternative approach relies on preserving the percolating networks during deformation via the engineering of the nanomaterials, elastomers, and assembly methods. For example, stretchable conductive inks consisting of long SWCNTs, ionicliquid gels, and a fluorinated copolymer rubber have been developed to afford a coating with a conductivity of 102 S cm−1 at 29% strain, or a conductivity of 10 S cm−1 at 118% strain.[404] Subsequently, Ag nanoparticles and nanoflakes were added into similarly formulated inks, which led to improved stretchability and conductivity, namely 20 S cm−1 at 140% strain.[403] Further development led to inks containing Ag nanoflakes modified with fluorine surfactants and a fluorinated copolymer rubber, which improved the conductivity to 182 S cm−1 at 215% strain.[402] While these inks contain high-aspect-ratio conductive nanomaterials, stretchable composites have also been developed based on Ag nanoparticles.[19,401] In one example, stretchable percolating networks were achieved through Ag-nanoparticle-coated rubber nanofibers, giving rise to 2200 S cm−1 at 100% strain.[401] In a different example, polyurethane/Ag nanoparticle composites were assembled by LBL assembly with high initial conductivities of 11 000 S cm−1.[19] In this case, the conductive pathways are restructured dynamically according to the applied strain as shown in Figure 9G.[19] This self-organized behavior leads to a conductivity of 2400 S cm−1 at 110% strain, and 35 S cm−1 at 480% strain.[19] A comparison of these stretchable conductors is provided in Figure 9C.
The properties of transparency and stretchability can also be concurrently incorporated, as has been demonstrated for SWCNTs[26] and Ag nanowires,[406,444] thereby enabling the fabrication of transparent and stretchable FETs.[35,406] An example is shown in Figure 9H.[406] These FETs employ a Ag-nanowire/ polyurethane acrylate composite as the source, drain, and gate electrodes, SWCNT networks as the channel, and a polyurethane copolymer as the dielectric.[406] The resulting devices can be stretched up to 50% strain (Figure 9I) and subjected to 500 cycles of repeated stretching without significant loss of output current or charge-carrier mobility.[406]

sections.heading: 7. Insulating Nanomaterials for Dielectrics
sections.text: Dielectrics are key components, separating the gate electrodes and semiconducting channels in FETs. As shown above, the areal capacitance (Ci) governs the output current with a higher Ci, inducing higher carrier densities in the semiconducting channels, thus allowing FETs to be operated at lower biases. Accordingly, high-capacitance dielectrics are in demand for low-power electronics.[447] The value of Ci is a function of the vacuum permittivity (ε0), and the dielectric constant (κ) and thickness (d) of the dielectric layer, according to the equation: Ci = ε0κ/d.[234] Therefore, dielectric layers in FETs should be engineered with small thicknesses and high dielectric constants. The first requirement is fulfilled with atomically thin nanosheets, which form ultrathin films by LB or LBL assembly,[121,130,234] whereas the second requirement is satisfied by high-κ nanomaterials.[259,260,411,448] In addition to high capacitance, dielectric layers should possess low leakage currents, low trap densities, and low roughness, for hysteresis-free and low-power device operation.[447,449]

sections.heading: 7.1. Thickness Control of Gate Dielectrics using 2D Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Atomically thin 2D nanomaterials with large bandgaps are promising candidates for gate dielectrics. The successful exfoliation of layered bulk materials, such as van der Waals solids (e.g., h-BN),[121] silicates (e.g., montmorillonite or MTM),[234] oxides (e.g., graphene oxide or TixO2),[450,451] and perovskites (e.g., Ca2Nb3O10 or Ca2La3O10),[130] has enabled the preparation of diverse 2D nanodielectric inks. Thin films can be fabricated from these inks by employing assembly methods with precise thickness control, such as LB and LBL assembly, for ultrathin, uniform, and large-area dielectrics with low leakage current and high capacitance.
LB assembly has been used to form ultrathin dielectrics from perovskite nanosheets.[130] In an example shown in Figure 10A, iterative deposition of monolayers of 1.5 nm-thick Ca2Nb3O10 nanosheets yielded a film with 10 distinct layers according to cross-sectional TEM and atomic force microscopy (AFM) imaging.[229,452] Subsequent annealing with a Xe lamp for 24 h allows the effective removal of the organic intercalants.[452] Other perovskite nanosheets have also been successfully assembled with this approach, including LaNb2O7, Sr2Nb3O10, and Ca2Ta3O10 nanosheets.[130,229,452,453] In addition to the extreme thinness afforded by LB assembly, these films also have large dielectric constants due to their inherent ferroelectricity (Figure 10B).[130] Specifically, the dielectric constant for Ca2Ta3O10 is ≈210.[130,229] These assembled dielectrics also show unchanged dielectric constants irrespective of film thickness, which is in stark contrast to the size-induced dielectric collapse (i.e., reduced dielectric constants) in normal perovskite thin films (Figure 10B).[130,229] In addition, the leakage current densities are smaller than 10−7 A cm−2 for 5-layer (7.5 nm) films at 2 V (Figure 10C).[130] The stable dielectric response and highly insulating nature remain unchanged even following annealing up to 600 °C.[454] FETs have been fabricated using these dielectric films,[130] although future optimization is necessary to fully
exploit their large areal capacitances. In addition to perovskite nanosheets, TixO2 and graphene oxide have been LB-assembled into large-scale thin films with dielectric constants of ≈120 and ≈3, respectively.[450,451] The graphene oxide films have been further utilized as dielectrics for flexible and transparent graphene FETs.[450]
LBL assembly is an alternative strategy for fabricating ultrathin dielectric films from 2D nanosheets. In comparison to LB assembly, LBL assembly is easier and faster to implement, and is compatible with highly scalable R2R processes.[232,455] During LBL assembly, randomly adsorbed nanosheets cover the substrates with a partial overlap, and post-sonication drives the nanosheets to tile in a manner similar to LB assembly.[456] The effectiveness of this process is exemplified by the assembly of DGU-sorted h-BN and MTM.[121,234] In order to achieve a high-quality assembled dielectric from colloidal h-BN inks, h-BN nanoflakes need to be as uniform and thin as possible. Consequently, thickness-sorted h-BN nanoflakes have been prepared by DGU, and then subsequently LBL assembled into ultrathin dielectrics.[121] The resulting h-BN dielectrics possess low leakage currents of 3 × 10−9 A cm−2 at an applied electrical field of 2 MV cm−1 in addition to capacitances of 245 nF cm−2.[121] AFM imaging shows that h-BN nanoflakes fully cover the surfaces with a slight overlap (Figure 10D), and cross-sectional TEM imaging indicates a distinctly layered structure (Figure 10E).[121] The inert and flat surfaces of h-BN thin films have enabled the fabrication of graphene FETs with negligible hysteresis and high mobilities up to 7100 cm2 V−1 s−1 (Figure 10F).[121] In another example, 1.6-nm thick MTM nanosheets were similarly LBL assembled.[234] The ≈7 nm-thick MTM dielectric films are highly uniform across an area of 5 mm × 4 mm with an average capacitance of 606 nF cm−2 and low leakage currents of 6 × 10−9 A cm−2 at an applied electric field of 2 MV cm−1 (Figure 10G).[234] These ultrathin MTM dielectrics have been implemented in p-type SWCNT FETs and n-type IGZO FETs with high-performance and low-voltage operation (Figure 10H,I).[234]

sections.heading: 7.2. High-κ Nanoparticle Inks for Gate Dielectrics
sections.text:
In addition to atomically thin nanosheets, high-κ nanoparticles have been explored as nanofillers in polymers for printable nanocomposite dielectrics. In particular, high-κ nanocomposites based on as BaTiO3 and TiO2 have been extensively studied for high-energy-density electrical-energy storage.[457,458] Furthermore, PMMA/BaTiO3 nanoparticles inks have been assembled into dielectric films using inkjet printing,[411] screen printing,[260] and gravure printing[259] for SWCNT FETs. These nanoparticles have typical sizes of more than 30 nm,[458] which presents challenges for ultrathin and low-roughness films. The dielectric constant of printed PMMA/BaTiO3 is ≈17 at a thickness of 1.5 μm, which corresponds to an average areal capacitance of 10.8 nF cm−2.[259] Despite such a small areal capacitance, SWCNT FETs can still be operated at biases of ≈10 V,[259,260] which can be attributed to the inhomogeneous electric field between the gate electrode and semiconducting channels due to the high roughness of the dielectric layer. Other high-κ nanoparticles, such as HfO2, have also been

For example, inks containing 50 wt% 25 nm-diameter HfO2 nanoparticles have been inkjet printed, resulting in di electric thin films with κ = 12.6.[459] A new synthesis method has recently been developed that produces ≈5 nm HfO2 nanoparticles,[460] which may further improve the quality of HfO2based printed dielectrics.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
Assemblies based on colloidal nanomaterials provide new electronic-material options with functionality beyond that of conventional microelectronics. Since these colloidal nanomaterials
are suspended in solution, a variety of assembly methods have been developed to fabricate and pattern thin films in a scalable manner. Furthermore, significant progress has been made to integrate these distinct nanomaterials into FETs and more complicated electronic devices and systems.[461] Due to their compatibility with transparent, flexible, and stretchable substrates, colloidal nanomaterials are leading candidates for emerging applications in wearable and biointegrated electronics.
While colloidal nanomaterials hold significant promise for consumer electronics, further effort is required to address many remaining problems, such as hysteresis, stability, device yield, and device-to-device variability. Furthermore, printing methods have limited spatial resolution and registry

Moreover, systematically understanding and engineering nanomaterial interfaces are likely to present pathways for overcoming performance barriers that limit solution-processed FETs. Commercial scale-up of nanomaterial synthesis, purification, separation, and assembly also holds promise for reducing the cost and thus expediting the transition of the fundamental research advances reviewed here to widespread technological applications.
